entry.title: Castner Range National Monument (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that to open for recreation, Castner Range National Monument (pictured) in El Paso's Franklin Mountains still needs to be cleaned of live munitions since closing as a weapons test site in 1966?

entry.title: Thierry Coquand (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Thierry Coquand won a SIGPLAN award for his eponymous proof assistant Coq, which was used to find a formal proof of the four color theorem?

entry.title: 1Point3Acres (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Chinese-language forum 1Point3Acres created a COVID-19 tracker used by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention?

entry.title: Mary Shadow (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Mary Shadow, the first unmarried woman in the Tennessee House of Representatives, received fourteen marriage proposals after her election?

entry.title: Ovid in the Third Reich (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the poem "Ovid in the Third Reich" has been described as "a classic reaction" to the Eichmann trial, despite being published before the trial was held?

entry.title: Airis Computer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Airis Computer's 1991 laptop could be powered with ten C batteries as an alternative to a rechargeable pack?

entry.title: Christian Keller (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Christian Keller worked as an academic before running SSV Jahn Regensburg?

entry.title: Seven (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Ned Beatty turned down the role of John Doe in the film Seven because the script was the "most evil thing" he had ever read?
